Disease # 6552 - Growth hormone deficiency

Other Names:

Categories: Endocrine Diseases

This disease is grouped under: Isolated growth hormone deficiency

Summary: Growth hormone deficiency (GHD) is characterized by abnormally short height due to lack (or shortage) of growth hormone. It can be congenital (present at birth) or acquired. Most cases are identified in children. Although it is uncommon, growth hormone deficiency may also be diagnosed in adults.[4421] Too little growth hormone can cause short stature in children, and changes in muscle mass, cholesterol levels, and bone strength in adults.[4422] Most of the time, no single clear cause can be identified but several genetic causes of GHD have been described, such as mutations in the to POU1F1/Pit1 , PROP1 GHRH and GH1 genes.[11634] In adolescents, puberty may be delayed or absent. Treatment involves growth hormone injections.[4421]

Learn More
  • ClinicalTrials.gov lists trials that are related to Growth hormone deficiency. Click on the link to go to ClinicalTrials.gov to read descriptions of these studies.

    Please note: Studies listed on the ClinicalTrials.gov website are listed for informational purposes only; being listed does not reflect an endorsement by GARD or the NIH. We strongly recommend that you talk with a trusted healthcare provider before choosing to participate in any clinical study.
  • The MAGIC Foundation provides information about this condition. The MAGIC Foundation provides support services for the families of children with a wide variety of chronic and/or critical disorders, syndromes and diseases that affect a child's growth.
  • The National Organization for Rare Disorders (NORD) has a report for patients and families about this condition. NORD is a patient advocacy organization for individuals with rare diseases and the organizations that serve them.
  • MedlinePlus was designed by the National Library of Medicine to help you research your health questions, and it provides more information about this topic.
  • Medscape Reference provides information on this topic. You may need to register to view the medical textbook, but registration is free.
    Growth Hormone Deficiency in Adults
    Pediatric Growth Hormone Deficiency
  • The Merck Manual for health care professionals provides information on Growth hormone deficiency.
  • Good Days provides help to patients with life-altering conditions. Assistance includes help with the cost of medications and travel.
  • The Endocrine Society has developed a Transitions of Care toolkit to help care teams ease the transition from a pediatric doctor to a new adult doctor.
  • The Pediatric Endocrine Society provides an online fact sheet entitled "Growth Hormone Deficiency: A Guide for Families."
  • The Pituitary Network Association provides a list of pituitary specialists.
